report_title: Industry Research: Historic Sites in the US
executive_summary: Operators of historic sites primarily preserve and exhibit sites, forts, buildings or communities that describe events or people of historical interest. Enterprises generally operate as nonprofit organizations and many are partnered with government organizations and receive public funding rather than gathering revenue from admission fees. Over the past five years, the industry has been experiencing volatile conditions due to inconsistent funding and high competition. Though operators have benefited from rises in disposable income rates early in the period, the COVID-19 pandemic exacerbated negative trends and resulted in drastic declines in visitor rates later in the period. Despite favorable conditions, industry revenue has been declining at an average annualized 0.5% over the past five years, reaching an estimated $1.5 billion in 2023, when revenue is expected to increase 6.0%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Industry Experienced Substantial Disruptions Amid the Height of the COVID-19 Pandemic
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Operators primarily generate revenue through in-person, self-generated sales, like admission fees, membership dues, concessions and accommodations, private and public donations, grants and endowments. Due to social distancing guidelines, many industry establishments were forced to cease or limit operations for much of 2020, resulting in drastically diminished revenue that year. This was compounded by a sharp fall in consumer leisure travel amid safety concerns and rising economic uncertainty.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Disposable Income and the Unemployment Rate Determines the Funds Allocated Toward Trips to Historic Sites
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Historic sites are sensitive to changes in disposable income, which affects the number of people who can visit historic sites and how much those visitors spend at sites or donate to them. Per capita disposable income has increased marginally, and though the national unemployment rate spiked in 2020 due to layoffs and furloughs following the spread of the coronavirus and social distancing measures, it decreased substantially since. This caused revenue to take a steep decline that year.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Industry is Expected to Recover Quickly From the COVID-19 Pandemic
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Historic sites bounced back from the detrimental operating conditions fairly quickly. Revenue stabilizes, thanks to improving economic conditions, and is expected to show stable growth for the next five years.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: An Increase in Domestic and International Tourism Leads to Growth in Visitors to Historic Sites
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: A rise in disposable income levels and easing health concerns, trips by domestic residents are expected to increase, boosting attendance rates at industry establishments. Income growth in emerging economies will help further spur foreign travel to the US, along with a projected decline in the value of the US dollar. The combination of these factors is anticipated to result in stable revenue growth as tourism to the US increases.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Historic Sites Continue to Rely Heavily on Tax Incentives and Government Funding to Cover Costs
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: This dependency is particularly true for enterprises owned by the government, like those operating under the National Park Service or in partnership with a government agency. Increased investment by local, state, or federal governments in the preservation and maintenance could improve visitor experiences and boost revenue.

industry_definition: Enterprises in this industry primarily preserve and exhibit sites, buildings, forts or communities that describe events or people of historical interest. These venues include archaeological sites, battlefields, historical ships and pioneer villages. Operators may be partnered with government organizations and receive public funding, gather revenue by charging admission and providing additional services or a combination of the two.

key_trends: Historic site operators preserve and exhibit sites, buildings, forts or communities that represent events or people of historical interest. Establishments range in venue type, from archaeological sites to historical ships and pioneer villages.

As disposable income levels rise and health concerns ease, trips by domestic residents are expected to increase, boosting attendance rates at industry establishments. Income growth in emerging economies will help further spur foreign travel to the United States, along with a projected decline in the value of the US dollar.

There has been an influx of non-US residents visiting the United States and residents travelling domestically. This grows attendance at industry establishments since more tourism leads to higher revenue gains for historic sites, helping to offset some of the losses from stifled government funding.

Most enterprises in the Historic Sites industry are managed by not-for-profit organizations, which are tax-exempt. There are also grants available from foundations that support heritage and culturally significant sites and associated activities, along with private donations and grants.

Historic sites are historic areas, buildings, structures, objects, battlefields or archaeological sites that generate revenue for preservation and exhibition purposes. Revenue can be generated through admission fees, special tours or traveling exhibits, membership services, food and beverage options, merchandise and government funding or donations from customers.

Consumers visiting establishments in the Historic Sites industry come from various locales, including metropolitan suburbs, cities and small towns. However, they tend to have higher-than-average educational backgrounds and tend to have higher income levels, with the majority of the industry's customers having an annual household income of more than $60,000.

The geographic distribution of establishments in the Historic Sites industry has remained stable. Although new sites continue to be formally registered, the largest and most prominent locations already operating have maintained an almost constant share of the distribution.

Operators of large historical sites have an already established reputation. They often remain prominent in the industry for long stretches, giving them an advantage against new entrants. Most industry operators are small and receive relatively few visitors annually. The significance of small sites keeps market share concentration from growing too high, while the established prominence of larger players keeps it from falling to a low level.

Operators in the Historic Sites industry operate with high fixed costs and fewer variable purchasing costs. Most operators are nonprofit entities and do not report traditional profit. Purchase costs are generally low in this industry. Wage costs tend to be higher, so operators allocate a large portion of funds toward wages and hiring highly skilled employees.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Individuals in the highest income quintile account for the majority of industry revenue. Families in the highest income quintile have a greater amount of disposable income to spend on discretionary activities like travel. These individuals are more likely to spend money on activities, gifts and hospitality services or make sizable contributions to historic sites. Due to their level of disposable income, industry operators rely on such consumers, as many require minimal or pay-as-you-wish donations for admission.

Individuals in the second, third and fourth income quintiles vary in their attendance of historic sites. Admission rates largely fall in line with per capita disposable income rates, the unemployment rate and consumer confidence.
Consumers in these quintiles have average disposable income, so they can frequent sites that charge admission fees when disposable income levels increase.

Individuals in the lowest income bracket (under $18,000) are expected to account for just 7.8% of industry revenue in 2023. Consumers in this income bracket are more likely to take advantage of free days or frequent sites that do not charge admissions.

products_and_services.product_description: Many nonprofit organizations rely heavily on government funding and grants, donations from patrons and endowments. When economic conditions are poor, and per capita disposable income and consumer confidence are low, individuals are less likely to make large or frequent donations.

Operators are raising admission fees or introducing them for the first time to attempt to cover losses incurred elsewhere. Many operators have attempted to keep admission to establishments free, pay-as-you-wish or simply low cost.

FAQs.question: With the options for recreational activities ever-increasing, how do you keep your historic site competitive in attracting time-strapped consumers?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators compete with similar industries, such as museums, national parks and zoos, for consumers with limited leisure time.

FAQs.question: How do you keep prices competitive in an industry where many operators offer free admission?
FAQs.answer: Many historical sites either charge no admission fee, offer pay-as-you-wish fees or keep admission fees nominal to remain competitive with alternative forms of entertainment.
